Hello and welcome to r/LifeProTips!

Please help us decide if this post is a good fit for the subreddit by up or downvoting this comment. 

If you think that this is great advice to improve your life, please upvote. If you think this doesn't help you in any way, please downvote. If you don't care, leave it for the others to decide.
Sending you a virtual hug and hope you get some much needed reprieve
SO TRUE! Stop thinking you are doing me a favor by visiting me! Come if i want you to come, don’t surprise me!
It's your home. Pro Life Tip, learn to say no.

Make a big list of things you should do but never have actually done and have them work through it. Things like:

Clean out the lint trap on your dryer
Clean out behind/under your stove or fridge
Properly clean the inside of your stove
Properly clean the washer, rubber seal, filter and all
Properly clean the dishwasher
Aerate the lawn

And anything else that are things you should do regularly. But never do.
As a Norwegian this is so weird. Who doesn't ask? Hahah

Hey Bob id like to come visit you sometime. Whats a good day and time for you?

This covers everything.

Damn. I hope the best for you :)

Btw I’m coming to visit you, don’t entertain me I’m coming to help

You need to reevaluate your priorities.

I get feeling obligated to be clean and awake. But makeup? In your own home while ill? All for a (supposed) loved one that forced their company on you and unlikely to judge you?

Idk, that doesn’t sound like you have enough self respect if you feel like you need to perform this much
Why don’t you just… say this to them? Like a normal, functional person?
I feel you in this. Currently going through serious Illness in the family and my sister in law just showed up an hour ago at 3 in the morning…smh

This is more just common courtesy though. People generally should ask if it is okey first before visiting, illness or not. 

 LPT from the situation is learning how to say no and making your boundaries clear to other people. 

These visitors are not just random people right? It is obviously people that care about you. Just tell them straight how you feel, and what you actually need/want from help.  

Doing all this might come off as being a total isolationist dick to well wishers. But it is a lack of not setting boundaries in the past that people think its okey to just visit you without asking your permission.
Also,  don't tell anyone you're just going to visit them. It should always be a question.
Does she really expect you to be this healthy? What's her rationale for coming to help then?! Tell her you need to sleep in and maybe she'll bring you breakfast in bed.

This sounds more like a MIL family issue.

Family seems to always overreact  when you need boundaries. And we are more sensitive
to these issues than with non-family.

Or, just don't go visit.  Most people that insist on visiting others that are ill or grieving are really doing so for themselves and have not considered in the least that it is not "helping" that person.

You don't HAVE to do anything. Say, "I'm sick and I need some alone time. I'm tired and while I'm okay, I don't feel like interacting with people and I want to veg out." If they don't want to listen to that then it's their fault. If you feel an obligation to let them come then it's your fault. If you aren't honest with people then you can't blame them for not doing what you want. At minimum, there is a certain percentage of people that would say, "Oh, I completely understand." 

Lack of communication is a huge problem. Tell people what you want!

No one expects you to prepare the guest room in your condition; if you are uncertain of this, tell your mil right now that she will need to prepare her room herself as you’re not up to it; tell her that you will be spending these last few days in your pjs 24/7, in bed  and relaxing. Ask her if she’s willing to come under those circumstances. Learning to set boundaries is an important life skill; so is learning to accept help when its offered and needed.
Oh god another awful im too self conscious to tell people no so you guys should accommodate to people like me thread
Illness or not, it should always be a request not an expectation of hospitality.
LPT - Stand up for yourself.

Closing your door for rest and naps throughout the day should be your new normal for the next few weeks then. I’m a total people pleaser and I like to be a great host but you have the right and the obligation to set limits. If you have naps/rest with your door closed starting day 1 then the precedent has been set. 

Feel free to explain to your guest that you need rest and that you’re not intending to be rude but relapse or delay in healing helps no one. Seriously.
You are healing and you require rest to do that. It’s up to to set those boundaries and assuming you don’t have young children in your care, then the adults can fend for themselves.

Do it for you!

I’m saying this as someone with chronic illness & disability - at some point you have to grow some balls and learn to tell people no.

Or you allow them to come for 2 hours and do x, y, & z tasks, then leave. 

You’re in control. Learning to say no is an important life lesson.
I've seen several LPT's about visiting. Can we all just agree it's never okay to announce your visiting? You should always ask.
I'd talk to my husband. Most of this is on you though. You not wanting to offend is damaging your own health.
